sp.p: Oh Sir, you cannot get to her, ſhe has lock'd her ſelf in her Chamber; and if you offer any violence, ſhe will call out to the Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: A Pox on her for falling in Love with me, and o' thee for telling me: find out ſome way of making an Interview betwixt us, or open wars will break out, and I will march to her Frontiers.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I cannot find out one, though I ſhould break my brain with ſtudy.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then keep thy brain whole, and I will break the door.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Hold Sir, hold Sir, ſince it muſt be ſo, I have thought of one: ſay after me as loud as ſhe may hear you, for her Chamber is but hard by, and we will ſee what that will do:—Excuſe me, Mrs. Andrews, for forcing my ſelf ſo rudely into your Ladies houſe.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Excuſe me, Mrs. Andrews, for forcing my ſelf ſo rudely into your Ladies houſe.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: It is an invincible paſſion which I have for your Lady.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: It is an invincible paſſion which I have for your Lady.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I muſt ſpeak with her now my Lord's abroad.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I muſt ſpeak with her now my Lord's abroad.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: If ſhe will ruine her reputation and be obſtinate ſhe may.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: If ſhe will ruine her reputation and be obſtinate ſhe may.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: For I dye if I do not ſee her.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: For I dye if I do not ſee her.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Now let me run and ſee how this has wrought: I muſt call to her through the key-hole.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: This Jade has heated me till I am all in a foam.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: This has done good:—ſince her Honour would be wholly ruin'd if there ſhould be any hubbub made, to preſerve her Honour, my Lady conſents to admit you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh ſweet Rogue!

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Not ſo faſt, Sir; you muſt ſwear not to divulge any thing.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I ſwear! what elſe?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I muſt run and tell her:—
sp.stage: (ſhe goes out, and comes in immediately.)
sp.p: And you muſt ſwear not to ſee her, or call for a light, or draw the windows or Curtains.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I ſwear, I ſwear.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I'le run and tell her:—
And you muſt ſwear not to talk to her, or at leaſt compell her to talk, to gueſs who ſhe is by her voice.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I ſwear I will not give her leiſure to talk; I will imploy her tongue otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: And you muſt ſwear not to touch her.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Nay then I ſhall be articl'd out of all: I will keep my paſt Articles, but I will not make one Article more.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p:
Well then, ſince it muſt be ſo, follow me,—follow me ſoftly;—ſoftly, that none of the Servants may hear.—Hold Sir, to let you ſee what an extraordinary eſteem my Lady
has of you, ſhe will truſt you with her Honour, and diſcover the beautiful Empire which your victorious charms have conquer'd:—See, Sir, this is the wounded Lady.

div.stage: The Scene is drawn, and diſcovers Chriſtina.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Christina! am I betray'd? Oh for an art to walk away inviſible.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Whither, whither, cruel Sir, are you conveying my felicity away, now I have taken ſuch pains to attain it? Oh uſe not that Empire Nature has given you over poor womens hearts too tyrannically! conſider we are poor ſoft loving things, and a little cruelty will kill us; have pity on a poor Lady that dyes for you, and is forc'd to deſcend from the modeſty of her Sex, to Court you to a minutes converſation, at an hour when the reſt of the happy world enjoy ſome their Loves, ſome their Repoſe, and all are at eaſe but poor me.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Jade, you will pay for this:—
Nothing can help me now but impudence:—So, Madam, you think you have put a fine trick on me now, you think you have catch'd me.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: I warrant you knew of the plot.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I warrant you think I did not.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Why did you?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Did I! a likely matter that I ſhould not know Iſabella's voice.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Why thou prodigy of impudence, dar'ſt thou impoſe ſuch a falſhood as this on me? I believ'd thee againſt the Reports of the whole world, which long ſince aſſur'd me of thy baſeneſs; but doſt thou think I will believe thee againſt the teſtimony of my eyes too? know I this minute tear thee out o' my heart, and after this never ſee me more.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ha, ha, what ſhall we jeaſt till we quarrel?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, here's your Father a coming; it ſeems he miſs'd you out of your Lodging, and is coming in a great rage to ſee if you be here.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ah what will he ſay if he catch me here? let me be gone, make room, make room.
sp.stage: Ramble creeps away at one door, enter at another Sir Tho. Raſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: So, Maid, have I found you out o'doors? go.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Who do you ſpeak to, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: To the corruption of my blood, to the diſeaſe of my ſoul, to the filth of my houſe, to the putrefaction of my honour; a blot which my Sword ſhould this inſtant ſcrape out of being, if the rent could be hid from the eyes of the world, or all the duſt of the Grave conceal thee.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Oh heaven!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Speak not, thy voice is more horrid to me then the groans of a Mandrake; thy ſight more odious then a Monſter; no ſence of mine will endure to hold communication with thee.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: Hey, hey! all this for an innocent frolick.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: For a Frolick! and an innocent Frolick! Oh the incomprehenſible Impudence of the Age! Lewdneſs is a Frolick, and abomination Innocence! Oh ſweet world, how art thou ſet with thy heels upwards ſince I knew thee!—Virtue and honeſty were Innocence, when I firſt came into thee; but now filthineſs is Innocence, and Hell and the Devil a Frolick! Oh that the Gout or a Greenland Froſt had ſeiz'd the fingers of the Deſtinies, e're they had ſpun out my thread to ſuch a Frolickſome Age.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Good Sir, why do you diſorder your ſelf, and afflict me, with theſe cauſeleſs tranſports? I know not the ſence of your diſcourſe; your language has to me no meaning; they are words never enter'd into my ears before; 'tis all diſtraction to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Oh you are for the ſubſtance, and not the Picture in words and phraſes:—I'le tell you my meaning more plainly: Then know, Mrs. Innocence, you are naught, you have been naught with Ramble; he own'd it, confeſs'd it, boaſted it to me, to my face, to my throat, with his tongue, with his Sword; he ſaid you had been lewd with him, and that you had been lewd before ever he touch'd you.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.p: Oh—

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: She ſwounds, ſhe ſwounds, help, help!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Let her dye; would ſhe had dy'd in the Cradle, in the womb, that ſhe might never have brought this ſhame and vexation to me.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: She has not, ſhe did not; none can ſay it, none did ſay it, none dare ſay it; or if they did, they lie, Ramble lies, and you lie, and you are all liars, and ſhould an Angel from Heaven ſay it, I would ſay he were a liar, and that ſhe has more Innocence then he.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You are her procurer, and now will be her maintainer, will you?—out o'doors.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: In this condition!—you are a natural Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: She's none of my daughter; her whole maſs o'blood, her whole body, her whole ſoul is chang'd.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: She is thy honour, thy glory.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Then Infamy follow me henceforward!—Go, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: She ſhall not go, I will defend her whilſt I have a nail, or a tooth.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
Nay then drag 'em hence; he that (to his Footmen. refuſes I'le drag to the Devil:—Go, to (they thrust them out. Ramble with her,—and after ſix months iniquity, when his beaſtly Appetite is gallop'd to his Journeys end, and is tired with whipping and ſpurring ſo long in the dirt, then to the Bawdy-houſes, and Common ſhops of Lewdneſs with her, and ſo to the Pox and Beggery, and ſo to Rottenneſs and the Grave, and ſo to the Devil;—an admirable Journey,—go.—Now will I with all ſpeed to the Writ-office, and take a Writ to arreſt my Lady Faddle in an Action of a Thouſand Pound, for breach of Articles: Sir Mannerly was by Covenant to be in Town, and the Marriage to be compleated, four days ago; he is not come, my daughter is debauch'd, my Family diſhonour'd, and all by means of their breach of Articles: it is not a Thouſand Pound can make me Reparation, I will not abate one farthing of what the Law will give me; and I will alſo have a pluck with that worthy Gentleman Mr. Ramble, I will try if there be no Law againſt inveigling young women to lewdneſs and naughtineſs: 'tis more then break of day; I'le go get the
Writ and Bailiffs, and ſee it ſerv'd my ſelf in perſon, before ſhe is up, my Bummers ſhall have her in bed.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Get my Coach ready, quickly.
How now, what rumbling's that?—Sis.

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: What's the rumbling within?

sp.speaker: Sis.
sp.p: Nothing, my Lord, but my Ladie's packing up her things to be gone, as you warn'd her laſt night.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: I had forgot it; is ſhe ſo capricious with me? I'le ſtay her, if it be but to croſs her.
sp.stage: (Goes out and re-enters immediately, pulling in Betty Friſque, followed by a Porter with a Trunk.)
sp.p: Sirrah, ſet down the Trunk.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sirrah, carry down the Trunk.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Sirrah, ſet it down, or I'le kick you down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sirrah, carry it down, or I'le break your neck down ſtairs.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Sirrah, ſtay a while, or I'le run my Sword into you:—ſince you are ſo humourſome, Gentlewoman, take your choice, your Trunks ſhall go and you ſhall ſtay, or you ſhall go and your Trunks ſhall ſtay: if I have not paid dear enough for you to have you be mine, I am ſure I have bought and paid enough for all that is in the Trunks, to diſpoſe of them.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Well, and I think I have paid dear enough for thoſe things, in enduring all your croſs jealous peeviſh humours.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: What jealous humours? I love you too well, that's my fault.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p:
Yes, indeed you love me very well, not to let me
breathe ſo much as a mouthfull of freſh air once in a month, and at home not to injoy an hour of quiet.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Yes indeed, I ſhould do wiſely to let you take the freſh air, as you call it; you never go to a Play, but you fall in Love with ſome young fellow; you never go to Hide-Park, but you are enamour'd with ſome rich gilt Coach; you never go to the Exchange, but you have a violent paſſion for ſome rich Point of fourty or fifty pounds value; that the Air is a dear Element to me: your freſh Air coſts me all my Earth almoſt.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I fall in Love with ſome young fellow! I deny your words, I defie you or any one in England to prove the leaſt falſhood in me to you, ſince I have known you: and for the gilt Coaches and Points, I have no more then what is convenient and neceſſary; I am ſure other women coſt other men twice as much as I coſt you: here are ſome that I can name, come to viſit me in a morning ſometimes with the richeſt Points, and the gloriouſeſt Petticoats, would dazle ones eyes to ſee 'em: I am ſure the faces of ſome of 'em, had need of 'em; their beauties are like thoſe of a Peacock, all in their ſhining tails.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Well, there's none of 'em all ſhould outſhine you, if you would be good-humour'd.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I do not know what you call good-humour'd; if I had not the patience of a Saint, I am ſure I could not bear with your humours.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Well, well, ſay no more, I hate this wrangling: have you any buſineſs at the Exchange this morning? I am ſending George thither.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No, not I.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Prithee give over theſe frumps, and fooleries; now I think on't, that Point you was offer'd for fourty pound was a good penniworth, I'le ſend for it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: You may and you will, but I'le ha' none on't.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Shall he call at the Jewelers as he goes by, for the Locket you had a mind to.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What you will: not for me.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p:
And well remembred, I will make him bring Mr. Draw-well the Limner along with him; I take it ill of him, he
has promis'd me to come any time this fortnight, and put me off from time to time, and yeſterday he promis'd to be here this morning: I will make him come and draw thee in theſe frumpiſh humours, that thou mayſt ſee how ill they become thee.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: He may come if he will, but I won't ſit.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Nor have any occaſion for the Point, or the Jewels.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Then George may ſpare his labour:—well, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Good morrow.
sp.stage: (he offers to go, and ſhe ſtops him.
sp.p: Well, the duce take you, what ails me to be ſo fond of nine and fifty? what have you done to bewitch me?
sp.stage: ſhe claps him on the cheek.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Ah Cokes!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: You have given me ſome Love potion, I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Aſſa-fotida,—and Garlick.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Confeſs, confeſs,—I could never be thus fond thus—

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Ah—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Blind! I am perfectly blind! I don't ſee a wrinkle; you appear a very Boy to me, a very Cupid.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Oh thou notorious wheedling ſlut, ſhall I ſtill put up ſuch impudent abuſes as theſe?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, and be glad of 'em too.

sp.speaker: Lord Dr.
sp.p: Well, Age is an abominable thing, it makes one pay dearer for the Lees, the dregs, the Vinegar of Love, then Youth does for the ſweeteſt, briskeſt Juice of the Grape: Well huſſey, George ſhall go:—I will pay the Tax you lay upon me; but 'tis hard a man ſhould pay ſuch deviliſh high Chimneymoney, and never have any fire.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: That's none of my fault, I am ſure I blow oft enough.

div.head: SCENE, The Street.
div.stage: Enter Sir Mannerly Shallow and Booby.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Well, did one ever ſee the like? what a brave place is this London? it is, as the Song ſays, the fineſt City-Town that ever I ſaw in my life.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Oh 'tis a brave place!—'tis not a City, 'tis a great Country, all o' houſes.—

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: It is, as the Poet ſays, the habitation of the Gods, Hominumque Deumque.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: What is that numque umque, an't like your worſhip?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Hominumque Deumque, Deumque for Deorumque, that is, of Gods and men.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: I never heard London call'd numque dumque before: 'tis a brave thing to be a Schollard; how chance your worſhip never came to numque dumque till now, but live in the Country all this while?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Thou talk'ſt like an Ignoramus; but I ſhall not trouble my ſelf to inſtruct thee:—Well, if I had known what a Gentile, what a Gallant place London was, my honourable Father ſhould not have ſtay'd me in the Country, though he would have married me to the fineſt Gentlewoman all round about, given me his Mannor-houſe, his Park, his Fox-dogs, and the beſt Hunting-Nags in the Stable: neither Dogs nor Nags, no nor my Lady Mother, ſhould have perſwaded me to ſtay.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Both his and her worſhip were too blame, an't like your worſhip, for ſtaying your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: For that trick as ſoon as ever I have married the fine Gentlewoman I come to Town to marry, for ſhe is but a Gentlewoman till I have married her, and then ſhe is a Lady; I ſay, as ſoon as ever I have married her, I'le ſtay here as long as I live, and never go into the Country again.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: I thought your worſhip ſaid you would go into the Country to ſell Lubbertown Woods.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Yes, I do intend to go into the Country for that; but I'le ſtay here as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: What a brave life ſhall we live here in this brave place, where all the houſes are as big as your worſhips Mannor, and all over nothing but folks!

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Ay, and all Gentlefolks!—and the civil'ſt Gentlefolks that ever I ſaw in my life: I no ſooner came into Town, and ask'd for an Inne, but an ancient grave Gentleman, that I am ſure muſt be an Officer in the Militia, Mayor of ſome Town, or a Knight, for he had a long great linen Scarf ty'd over croſs his ſhoulders, by that I thought him a Major, or a Colonel in the Militia; but he had over that a great Silver Chain, like our Mayors Chain, by that he ſhould be the Mayor of ſome Town.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: May be he is Mayor of a part of this City, an't like your worſhip, for this is too big to have but one Mayor.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Ay, but then he had on his breaſt a great round Silver thing, as big as the bottom of our great Silver Sugardiſh, with his Coat of Arms upon it, by that he ſhould be ſome London Knight:—but one of theſe three I am ſure he muſt be; and of his own accord he came to my very horſe-ſide, ſhew'd me an Inne, and held my Stirrup in ſpight of my teeth whilſt I lighted; I never ſaw ſuch a civil perſon ſince I was born:—he made me ſo aſham'd, that all I could ſay was to intreat him to do me the honour to accept of a poor Supper with me at my Inne: and Anthony Boody, do you ſee to find him.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: I ſpoke to his worſhip, and he promis'd he would come without fail.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: See that the Mutton-broath have white-bread Sippets in it, and all things be order'd handſome, as our Cook-Maid us'd.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: I ſhall, an't like your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: But this was not all: I had no ſooner taken my leave of the ancient Gentleman, and gone to the Street-gate, but a Coach-man of his own accord came and civilly tender'd me a Coach to carry me.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: The Horſes were ſomething lean, an't like your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p:
I ſuppoſe 'tis ſome Complementing-Coach kept o'
purpoſe to Complement Strangers; and abundance of Strangers coming to Town, the Horſes might be worn out with much Complementing: for I perceive it is the cuſtom here to Complement Strangers ſo; for I had no ſooner thank'd the Coachman, given him ſomething for his civility, and preſented my ſervice to his Maſter, but at leaſt half a dozen more Complementing Coaches came up to me as hard as they could drive, to proffer their ſervices.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: I believe the Gentry has been told how ready your worſhip is at any time to lend your beſt Team to any Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: No, no, I ſaw 'em do the ſame to twenty more as well as my ſelf:—well, 'tis the civil'ſt place that ever I came in days of my birth: for I'le tell thee more, Booby, after I had gone a little way in a great broad Street, I turn'd into a Tavern, hard by a place they call a Park; and juſt as our Park is all Trees, that Park is all Houſes, you cannot ſee ſo far as you can ſpit:—and I ask'd if they had any Deer in it; and they told me, Yes, but not half ſo many as they us'd to have; they us'd to have the beſt Deer in all the Town, and ſcarce a Veniſon Paſty was formerly made, that had not the Veniſon out of their Park: But they ſaid the Park was now quite ſpoil'd, and the beſt Deer were all gone to the other end of the Town, and thoſe that ſtay'd were poor Raſcal Deer, not worth baking.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: I don't wonder they are poor, an't like your worſhip, for I did not ſee a bit of Graſs, except ſome ſprinklings among the Stones, and a little mouthfull here and there on the tops of houſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I warrant the Deer here a kind of Goats, and climb on houſes to brouſe: I had a great mind to taſt 'em, and ſpoke for a Paſty; and they told me the ſtrangeſt thing, they ſaid their Rooms were full of cold Paſties, ſo big two people might ſleep in one; and that if I had a mind to a Doe, they would put me in a Paſty, and put a Doe to me.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Oh ſtrange! and did your worſhip go into a Paſty!

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p:
No, I'le tell you what happen'd: juſt as I ask'd for the Doe, in comes a couple of young Gentlewomen, the handſomeſt,
fineſt Gentlewomen that ever I beheld, Mrs. Anne Lackwit the great Beauty of Lubbertown is nothing to 'em; and they were all over Lace, and had the fineſt, reddeſt Cheeks and Lips, that ever I ſaw: no ripe Cherry is ſo red; they were ſo red, that the blood came off the very out-ſide of their Lips, and as I kiſs'd 'em left a redneſs on mine.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Is't poſſible! I warrant your worſhip kiſs'd 'em too hard, you made their teeth bleed, and that was the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: No, no, it was the very blood of their Lips, that was dry'd on.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Well, I never ſaw the like!

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: No, nor I neither; for I had no ſooner ſaluted 'em, to ſhew my breeding, but they of their own accord took me about the neck, and kiſs'd me as if they had been my Siſters, or as if they had known me theſe twenty years, that I fell ſo in Love with them, that i' my conſcience if I had not been ingag'd already, I had married the handſomeſt of 'em before I came away.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Is't poſſible! but did not your worſhip ask for the great Paſty.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I ſhould ask for victuals before Gentlewomen, ſhould I? that were fine breeding: No, but they of their own accord were ſo civil as to invite me up ſtairs to a Paſty; and juſt as I was going up with them, I chanc'd to put my hands in my pockets, and as if the Devil had been there, my money was all flown out of my pocket, I know not how, nor whither.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Flown out of your worſhips pocket!

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I, flown out o' my pocket.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: What of it ſelf!

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I, of it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: And no body to help it!

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: There was no body near to help it.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: What all!
Sir Man All but one Six-pence, that was in a corner of my pocket.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: There muſt be witchcraft in this, and if I was your worſhip I would make that Six-pence find out all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: How like a fool thou talk'ſt; how can that Six-pence find it out, when I could not find it my ſelf, though I look'd up and down in every corner oth' houſe; nay the Gentlewomen were ſo very civil as to help me, nay would have come out to help me look it in the Streets, if I would have let them.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Well, this was old Goody Wrinkle-noſes doings, that lives on the ſide of your worſhips Woods by Lubbertown; if I were your worſhip I would write down into the Country, and have her hang'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Nay I am ſure it was the Devil, for I remember as the Gentlewomen were kiſſing me, I felt a thing ſcratch in my pocket juſt like a Rat.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Nay then it was Goody Wrinkle-noſe, and the Devil has brought her to Town before us: if I were your worſhip I would make her an example.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Nay I do intend to trounce her, for this is demonſtration:—Well, but now what ſhall I do to find my Aunt, my Lady Faddle, for I have loſt my directions; all I can remember is, that ſhe lives in a place they call the Pall-Mall: and the Pall-Mall I find, but cannot find my Aunts houſe: and ſhe is to help me to find out my Baronet Father-in-Law, Sir Thomas Raſh; where I ſhall find his daughter Mrs. Christina, whom I am bound in a Bond of a Thouſand Pounds, with my Aunt my Lady Faddle, to marry four days ago: and my Lady Aunt writ me word, that my Baronet Father-in-Law was very angry for my not coming; and if I did not marry Mrs. Chriſtina, and come up to day, he would take the forfeiture of the Bond.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: See, an't like your worſhip, here comes the ancient Gentleman that you invited to Supper, that held your Horſe; if he be Mayor of any part of the Town, as he looks to be, it may be he can tell whereabout your Lady Aunt lives.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Bud, here are the Complementing people, let me get away from them.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p:
Hold, worthy Sir; noble Sir, I do not know how
to return the great favours and honours you were pleas'd to confer on me, who am but a Peregrine: I commanded my man Booby to intreat you to accept of a ſmall Supper with me, not as a return, for I know you have a better Supper at home, but as it were to ſhew how much I am oblig'd for all your Noble favours: Now, worthy Sir, I make bold to requeſt you to adde one favour more to all your paſt favours, to acquaint me if you have any acquaintance with a Lady and Aunt of mine, by name Lady Faddle.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Well, I have ply'd here theſe fourty years, and never met with ſuch an odd ſort of a Blade in my life:—who is it you ask for?

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: An Aunt of his worſhips, one Lady Faddle.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: I do not know her, Maſter, I cannot direct you.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: This is ſtrange, that no body can tell where my Lady Aunt ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: I think in my conſcience, an't like your worſhip, I have asked above a hundred folks for her, and not one knows where ſhe ſhould be; no nor ſo much as knows her worſhip: nay I ask'd all about the Neighbourhood, and the very Neighbourhood did not ſo much as know her worſhip.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: You muſt not think you are in the Country: People do not know one another here, that live in the ſame Street, nay in the ſame Houſe, nay ſometimes that lie in the ſame Bed together.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Hey day! why I know all the Gentry round me in the Country, for above Twenty mile.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Ay, but 'tis not ſo here.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: How do they do not to know one another? do they do it on purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: People never mind one another here, unleſs they have buſineſs together; but let them go as they come, and come as they go.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Hey day! why I know all the Dogs and Horſes in the Country that are eminent, whether I have any buſineſs with them or no.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Ay, but you may be a Dog, or a Horſe, or a Man here, no body will mind you, unleſs they have ſome concern or other with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Hey day, I never heard the like!

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Nor I in my life.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Then if I ask a thouſand people for my Lady Aunt, there's no body knows her.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: You may ask ten thouſand before you meet with one that knows her.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Hey day! then I ſhall forfeit my Bond, for. I ſhall not find her to help me to find Mrs. Christina, before the Sun is ſet; what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Your worſhip can prove you were come to Town, and ſo if you cannot find 'em, the fault is none of your worſhips.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Ay, but I did not think I could not find 'em, and ſo there is no ſuch clauſe in the Bond; for I am bound to marry Mrs. Chriſtina whether I can find her or no.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Then I'le tell you what your worſhip ſhall do; ſend for a Vicar, and ſay over your worſhips part, and then you can prove you have done all that belongs to your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I ſwear that's very well thought of; for now I think on't, I ſeal'd and deliver'd the Bond in the Country to my Baronet Father-in-law's uſe, without his being preſent, or ever ſeeing of him in my life: ſo I will ſend for a Parſon, and marry my ſelf to one of you two, for Mrs. Chriſtina's uſe, and this will be as good in Law as if ſhe were preſent.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: Right; for if the Marriage be not good, then how is the Bond, ſince they are both made after the ſame manner?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Do theſe men Jeſt, or are they as errant Fools as they ſeem? I believe they are Fools; for I never heard ſuch a deal of ſimple ſtuff and complementing, as I have had with them to day, ſince I was born.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I ſwear this was the beſt thing that ever was thought on: now do not I care whether I find my Aunt or no.

sp.speaker: Boo.
sp.p: This old Gentleman's worſhip having been with you ever ſince your coming to Town, your worſhip had beſt ask his worſhip to be a witneſs, and ſee you married to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I can have no better witneſs, for he can prove all: Noble and obliging Sir,—

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Now he falls a Complementing again: I wonder he ſtayd ſo long from it: I would the Devil had his Complements, he has made my head ake:—Hold, hold, Maſter, ſpare me for Heaven's ſake; I remember my Lady Faddle, ſhe once ſent me of an Errand; your Complements buzzl'd me, and put it out of my head: I know where ſhe lives, I'le lead you to her houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh Sir, what favours do you confer upon me!—But Sir, you ſhall not go a' foot; Booby, fetch my horſes.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Horſes! my feet are my Pad-nags.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh Sir, you will ſwell your high obligations to ſuch a—

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Swell my thighs with hobbling! no, no, hobbling is my Trade.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Well, to Cumberland commend me for Gentility, But to London for good Breeding and Civility.

div.head: SCENE I. The Street.
div.stage: Enter Sir Mannerly, Booby, and Porter.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: LOok you, Sir? you are now at the door?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh Sir, why do you condeſcend to give your ſelf the trouble of knocking.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Is my Lady Faddle within?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Who would ſpeak with her?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Her Nephews-Worſhip, Sir Mannerly Shallow and I, are come to Town, tell her.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Preſume to ſpeak before me? where's your Manners? Sir, I am her humble Servant, Nephew, and Baronet, Sir Mannerly Shallow.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Oh dear Sir? are you Sir Mannerly Shallow? my Lady expected you this morning early; ſhe will be mighty glad you are come: ſhe is within, pleaſe to walk in, Sir, whilſt I run in, and acquaint her of your coming?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: This is good luck? Noble Sir, I beſeech you, honour me ſo far, as to walk in with me.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Oh Maſter what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I beſeech you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Come, pray your Worſhip, walk in.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: What do theſe People mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Nay, but Sir, I am to be married to night, and I ſwear I will not Marry, if you will not Grace my Nuptials with your Preſence; therefore, Sir, if your affairs call you away now, yet promiſe me, on your Honour, that the joys of my Marriage, ſhall be increas'd with the happineſs of your company; your Preſence will be the Principal Diſh at my Feaſt.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: He means to diſh me up, well Maſter, if you want any body to wait, and go of Errands, Ile promiſe you Ile come.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Your moſt humble Servant, I will not reſt, till I requite your Civilities.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: What odd kind of contriv'd Men are theſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Booby, Do you carry your ſelf well now, before my Lady Aunt, and do not diſparage me, obſerve what I do, and then you'll do finely.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Faddle, Bridget, and Servant.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: My Nephew come? this is good news, where is he? introduce him ſpeedily.
Sweet Nephew:
sp.stage: She runs forward to ſalute him, he ſtill goes backward, and Compliments.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Honourable Aunt! The extream Joys and Felicities of your Society, which a long Parentheſis of time has interrupted, but now Time, as it were penitent—

sp.speaker: Lady Fad.
sp.p: Why doſt not ſalute me, Nephew?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Yes Madam, as ſoon as ever I have done my Compliments.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Oh, thou ſhouldſt ſalute the firſt thing thou doſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Yes Madam, but a Salute being a kind of a Preſent, or rather Tribute to a Lady, and as one would not preſent an empty Purſe for Tribute to a Princeſs, ſo neither an empty Mouth to a Lady, but as full of Rich and Golden Compliments, as it could hold.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: This is witty to extremity, I ſwear; Salute me, that I may be at leiſure to praiſe thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Your moſt Humble Servant, Aunt.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Your Worſhips moſt Humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: How now Saucebox, kiſs my Aunt?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Did not your Worſhip bid me obſerve what you did?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Did I bid you kiſs Ladies of quality?

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: What rude fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Forgive him Aunt—'tis his want of breeding.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Well, Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Bid John run with all ſpeed, to Sir Thomas Raſh; and acquaint him my Nephew is come, and run to my Milleners, for my Gloves, and Eſſences, and run to the Exchange, and run to my Coach-makers for my new Harneſs, and run for my new Towre, and run—

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I ſhall run, Madam, to bid him run, or otherwiſe the poor fellow will be made to run all over the Town.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Well Nephew, thou wilt enjoy to night, a delicate Lady, I have ſo exalted thee to her, with exuberant praiſes, that it will require a great expence of Wit and Breeding, to maintain the Glorious Character I have given thee: Come, give me an account how thou haſt ſpent thy time? how haſt thou improv'd thoſe Documents, and Rudiments of good Breeding, which I inſtill'd into thee.—

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh Madam, I have improv'd every Document, not a ſlip of a Rudiment your Ladiſhip Set, but is grown up to a Flower. Indeed, my Father did all he could to ſpoil me; he would let me read nothing in his life-time, but Law-Books, Cook upon Littleton, and Books of Reports, and Judges Reports, and I read Reports and Reports ſo long, till it was reported I was a Fool.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Ay, but your Worſhip now reads Comedy Books, and Prodigy Books.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Tragedy Books thou meanſt, ay, and Songs, and Verſes, and Drolleries, Covent-Garden Drollery, Weſtminſter Drollery, and Windſor Drollery.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Very well, This is as to the accompliſhment of the Mind; but now to the External Ornaments of the Body, as Dancing, Singing.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh, I have had Dancing-Maſters, Fencing-Maſters, and Singing-Maſters.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Ay, thoſe Maſters muſt make thee fit to be a Servant to Lady's.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I can Dance Corantoes and Jiggs, and Sarabands.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: And Hornpipes.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Canſt thou Riſe well?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: In a morning, Madam.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: His Worſhip gets up by break of day.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: No, Riſe high in Dancing, if you will riſe high in Ladies favours here, you muſt riſe high in Dancing, that is to ſay, Dance loftily.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh, I can Dance very loftily.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: The countrey ſays, his worſhip carries himſelf too loftily.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Make an Eſſay of a lofty Dance.
Very Graceful, I ſwear, and very lofty.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Oh; his Worſhip will jump like any Jack-Daw, that has but one wing cut.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Jack-Daw, firrah? don't you make ſuch ſaucy compariſons.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Well Nephew, thou wilt kill a great many Ladies this Winter, thoſe Heels will advance thee, thou wilt jump into Preferment; I ſee a witty Man is good for any thing; one would wonder thou ſhouldſt jump ſo high, with ſuch a weighty Brain in thy Head.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: As heavy as a Pail of Milk.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Thou art ingenious at both ends, both thy Head and thy Heels; its rare for one to be witty, more than at one end; well Nephew, thou wilt dance away all thy Countrey Eleſh this Winter; thy Heels will be invited to ſhew their parts to Dance, in every fine Entry, in the Masques and Plays, and—

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Why do they Dance in Entries here? we Dance in the Countrey in our Halls and Dining Rooms, becauſe the Entries are too narrow:

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Oh fy, thou doſt not underſtand the terms of thy own Art yet; to Dance in an Entry, that is to ſay, in an Entry, an Entry of any thing—

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Of Freeſtone or Brick?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Your Worſhip's are all Free-Stone.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: No, no, fy fy, expert in the Science, and ignorant in the Terms, in an Entry of Shepherds or Gods, and Goddeſſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I can Dance in any Entry in England.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Strange, that thou ſhouldſt not apprehend me; but to let that paſs—well, but how is thy ſinging?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Oh, his Worſhip out-ſings all our Pariſh, at Church, the Clark is aſham'd to ſet the Pſalm before him.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Sing a Pſalm, I have ſung my part in a Recitattivo (as they call it) I had a Recitattivo acted at my own Houſe: and I acted in it, and ſung, I was London, or Auguſta, and I had a high crown'd Hat, to ſignify Pauls Steeple, and I had one acted the River Thames I had a great Noſe made on purpoſe to ſignify London Bridge, and the River Thames ſwom under my Noſe, I have my Noſe in my Portmantua, if I had it on, you ſhould ſee Booby, and I would Act.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Then thou canſt Act Nephew.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: And ſo can I too.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh, I have all the new Comedy Books, and Tragedy Books, ſent me, as faſt as ever they are made; oh, I love them that huffe the gods, they make no more of a god, then we do of a Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Your Worſhip and I acted a Tragedy Book, you know.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Yes, and I was an Hero, and I remember two of the braveſt lines.
sp.l: If ſaucy Jove, my Enemy appears,

l.hi: I'll pull him out o' Heaven by the Ears.

sp.p: There's ramping for you.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Saucy Jove, that's very great, that took mightily here.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Oh that Rumm-Dumm, Derry Dumm, oh, but the two Knocking Verſes, an't like your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh, ay, you muſt know, my Part, Aunt, was to beat an Army, and ſo when I had beaten an Army, and two Armies more that came to their relief, and won four Kingdoms in three hours; I cry'd, Let me ſee, it's a little out of my Head; I cry'd, Ile, Ile, Booby, thou canſt think of it.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: O yes, an't like your Worſhip, I can remember it perfectly, Ile, Ile, Mackings, I ha forgot it, I ha dropt it upon the Road ſomewhere.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: What a Noddle haſt thou, thou actedſt with me.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Ay, but your Worſhip kill'd me, before you ſpoke the Speech: the Butler, the Ploughman, and I, was the Army.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I did not kill thee in earneſt did I? Let me ſee, Ile.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Oh, now I remember, ſingle, it begins with ſingle—

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.l: Oh ſingle, ſingle, it begins with ſingle.

l.hi: My ſingle Sword, both men and gods ſhall maull,

sp.p: Oh but the next is the braveſt.

l.hi: I will kill all the World, nay more than all.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.l: There's your Rowzers.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.l: There's your Thumpers.

sp.speaker: Lad. Fad.
sp.p: Oh, they have a brave ingenious way of Writing now.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh, but then the fine tender things that would make one cry, you muſt know, Aunt, my Part, was to be in Love with my Dary-Maid, and her name was Celemena, and mine was Philaſter, and I cry'd.
sp.l: How does my faireſt Celemena do?
sp.p: And ſhe cry'd
sp.l: Thank you my dear Philaſter, how do you?

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Very natural and ſoft.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Oh, the Dary-Maid is very ſoft.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh, but then the two next are tender,—I cry'd,

l.hi: Does my Sweet-heart me any kindneſs bear?

sp.p: And ſhe cry'd,
sp.l: I love you dearly, now, I vow and ſwear.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Very Tender.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Oh, Mary is a very tender good natur'd Maid.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Tender as an over-boil'd Chick.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Very wittily compariſon'd, the Sence is ready to drop in pieces, 'tis very fit for Womens weak Stomachs.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh, but when my Maid and I came to dy, I don't know why we were to dye, but we dy'd mighty mournfully, and then I having learnt to ſing, I groan'd ſo Muſically, I dy'd in effaut flat, Oh, cry'd I!

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Oh, that was ſweet.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh, but then the Similies, I love the Similies dearly, to ſee two Heroes, or two Armies go to it as formerly, with Sword and Buckler, ſo now with Sword and Simile, Simele and Sword; Hack-ſlaſh, Slaſh-hack, for you muſt know, a Simile ſerves inſtead of a Buckler, for if a Man be ready to ſtrike another, if t'other up's with a Simile, he can't ſtrike till the Simile's gone.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Oh, they have a fine way.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Ay, and then they have ſuch plenty of Similies you ſhall have a Play ſtuck as full of Similies, as a Countrey Garden, of Flowers, you may gather Poſies o'Similies.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Wittily ſaid again, ſtuck full o'Similes, and Poeſies of Similies: I ſwear, thy Head is as full of Similies, as the Plays are.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh Sir, a witty man's Head is a Similies Bed, and breeds Similies as faſt as an Oyſterbed breeds Oyſters.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Witty again, he has ſtrange parts.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: And then they have the fineſt odd, out of the way Similies, Similies that are moſt commonly no Similies at all, as now, ſpeaking of a Ladies bright Eyes, ſays one,

l.hi: How do the nimble Glories of her Eye,
Frisk, and Curvett, and ſwifily gallop by.

sp.p: There's a fine compariſon, to compare a Ladies Eye to a Horſe.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Ay, and Nimble is a fine odd, out of the way, Epithete for Glories, Nimble Glories. Well, dear Chuck, how cameſt thou by all this admirable, and, as I may ſay, Nimble Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: You muſt know, I had a couple of gallant Gentile Blades lay at my Houſe, that were Great Men in London, here they are call'd Critwiques, and they taught me the fineſt things.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Oh, the Critiques are Great Men indeed, they make Poets as fraid of them, as a Lion is of a Cock.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Some ſay, that is not at all.

sp.speaker: La Fad.
sp.p: An old Lion, it may be, is not, nor an old Poet, of a Critique, but your new Poets are ſo afraid of them, that if a Critique Crows, they are ready to faint away.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Is't poſſible? could not one buy a Criticks Place?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Pray your Worſhip do, and let me be your Clark.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Buy, alaſs thou mayſt Judge and Critick for thy half Crown, as much as thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: That's a pittiful Place, if one can buy it for half a Crown.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Oh, but the Clark may get Money though.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: 'Tis not Money, but Wit makes a Man a Critique.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Then I am a Critique already.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Oh brave, then I am a Clark?

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Well, dear Fleſh and Bloud o'mine, let me imbrace thee, that I may ſay, I have my Arm full of Wit, thou art a Bridgroom for a Princeſs; how wilt thou honour my Education? well, haſt thou brought up any Clothes to be Married in?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: My Portmantle full.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Go and adorn thy ſelf with all ſpeed, whilſt I prepare for the ſame affair, for I am to be Married, as well as thy ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Andrew, Madam, has been at Sir Thomas Raſh's, and can hear no tidings, neither of Sir Thomas, nor Madam Chriſtina; Madam Chriſtina lay out all night, and is not come home ſince; Sir Thomas is gone ſomewhere in a great combuſtion, and the Servants can give no account of either of 'em.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: That's ſtrange, oh, Ile warrant you, they'l be heard on, Nephew, go and dreſs thy ſelf, mean while Ile ſtep to the Exchange, for ſome things I want, and after that, Ile go over and invite Betty Frisque to my Wedding, I have much kindneſs for that poor Creature.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: So you ſee, Madam.
I bring to Town, a Mind, and Wit in faſhion,
And doubt not but to grace your Education.

div.stage: The Scene changes to the Street.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Into what a villanous Trap am I fall'n, dull Rogue that I was, not to know Iſabella's voice, where were my Ears, my Sences? they were all in my Pocket, I was tickled with my raviſhing expectations, into a perfect numneſs to death, now am I diſcover'd in all my Rogueries, and Intrigues, and Falſhoods; and muſt never hope to enjoy the ſweet pleaſure of Lying and Forſwearing any more; I muſt now either repent, and become a down right plodding Lover to Chriſtina, or in plain terms loſe her: I muſt either forſake all the World for her, or her for all the World: well, if I do forſake her, ſhe has this to boaſt, I do not forſake her for any one Woman, I forſake her for Ten thouſand. But what do I talk of forſaking her, will not ſhe forſake me, after this diſcovery? and beſides her own Anger, will not Sir Thomas compell her? for he is horribly provok'd againſt me, what ever the matter is. Well, I cannot bear the loſs of Mrs. Chriſtina, I had rather endure Marriage with her, than injoy any other Woman at pleaſure—I muſt, and wil • Repent, and Reform, and now ſhould an Angel appear in Female ſhape, he ſhould not tempt me to revolt any mor • .
Oh Merry I am ruin'd

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
O • , Sir, you are a happy Man, I have not time to ask
you the ſucceſs of your laſt Adventure, I am ſo tranſported with the pleaſure of the Preſent; cannot you Limne, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Limne, what doſt thou mean?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why Limne, Sir, draw Pictures in little.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I, draw Pictures?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Yes, Sir you can, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But I cannot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: But you can, Sir; you can Limne, and you muſt Limne, and you ſhall Limne, Sir. Coming along by Charing-Croſs, who ſhould it be my fortune to meet with, but Mr. Draw-well the Limner, going in all haſte to my Lord Dry-bones, to draw Mrs. Frisques Picture—and what comes into my Head, Sir, but to beg of him to write an Apology for not coming, and ſend you with it, to perform the Work in his ſtead; and to prevail with him, I promiſed him the gain of the Picture, without the trouble.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Thou haſt undone me, ſeduc'd me from the ways of Virtue and Conſtancy. Juſt as I was entring into 'em, I am not able to reſiſt the temptation of this Plot, but how ſhall I manage it? for I can no more make the Picture of a Face, than I can make a Face; I have not ſo much skill, as a Man may learn out of The Compleat Gentleman, and other elaborate Pieces that teach that Faculty.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, Sir, Did not I hear you the other day in a Mercers Shop, promiſe his Wife her Picture, in the Preſence of ſeveral Ladies, and the Good Man ſcrap'd you many Legs, to expreſs his extraordinary Sence of ſo great a favour, and ſaid, he would wait upon you, with his Wife, at your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Thou ſayſt right, glowing with extream appetite to her, my Tongue and Brain over-heated with Motion, in the Stream and Whirlpool of thought and babble, I very impudently invited her to ſit to me for her Picture, and the fooliſh Cuckold her Husband did accordingly bring her, and leave her with me; where, when I had ſqueez'd his Orange, I gave him the Rin'd again; and requited him with the ſhadow of it, Drawn by one that could perform it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Can you not draw then, Sir, what ſhall we do? our Plot is ſpoil'd.

sp.speaker: Ramb,
sp.p: Not at all, Sir, I can Draw well enough for my purpoſe, by this Plot, I may Draw her, as I did the Mercers Wife, that is, I may Draw her to my Chamber, that's enough.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: That's very well thought on, and to continue the quibble, this Plot will give you a colour to viſit her.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Well quibled again, where's the Apology, is that as witty.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: A good honeſt, plain Countrey Apology.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Come along Merry, thou muſt help in this buſineſs; well, I muſt turn thee away, before thy wicked Councils have undone me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, it is ill done of me, but it is done out of pure pity, like a good Natur'd Nurſe, that cannot forbear giving a Feavoriſh Creature, that is ready to dye of Thirſt, what Drink they crave; I cannot for my life, hear you groan aft era Wench, night and day, ſo pittifully, and not help you.
sp.stage: Enter Lord Drybone, and Betty Frisque.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Go, go, Huſſey, you are an unkind naughty Girl, to make me pay thus dear for every ſmile and ſmirk I get from you; I dare ſafely ſay, not a dimple you make, when you ſmile, that does not coſt me, one with another, Forty pound a Dimple.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: 'Tis your own fault, my dear Lord, you will be chiding o' one, and quarrelling with one.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Chiding o' one, and quarrelling with one; ay, and I had better quarrel on, I am a fool to buy Peace ſo dear, conſidering what a poor Trade I have, and how little I get by it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: People that cannot barter Commodity for Commodity, muſt ſend Money in ſpecie, you know they do it all the World over.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: But that's a very ruinous Trade, one had better War with ſuch a Countrey, and forbid all traffique with it, my dear Frisky.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ay, if one can live without it, my dear Lord, you.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Come, no more of this, prepare to ſit, Mr. Draw-well's a coming, I am glad you like your Point, and Jewel, it puts you in good humour, and makes you the fitter to ſit.

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.p: There's one below from Mr. Draw-well, deſires to ſpeak with your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: How, has he fail'd me again? what an unworthy fellow it is, he ſhall never draw it now, though he will do it for nothing.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: May be he has not fail'd you, my Lord, ſend for the Man up, and know his Meſſage.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Let the Man come up:
Theſe ſort of Fellows, if they grow any thing famous, they grow ſo ſaucy with it, that they are not to be indured.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I come from Mr. Draw-well, my Lord—he ſends this Letter by me to your Lordſhip.
sp.stage:
(L. Drybone opens the Letter, and Reads.
My Noble Lord,—Fortune maliciouſly, juſt as I was upon the—way a coming, I have, by much importunacy, obtain'd the extraordinary kindneſs of this Gentleman, to come in my room, one of the firſt Men in the World,—formerly my Scholar;—have a care (I beſeech your Lordſhip) not to ſpeak to him of any recompence, for he is a Gentleman of quality, and draws onely for his own divertiſement.
Your Lordſhips humble Servant
DRAW-WELL.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: This Gentleman come to Draw my Picture? I know him, I love him for this Piece of Ingenuity, I ſwear.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Sir, this is a great favour, indeed, I will aſlure you, Sir, I take it for a great Honor, ſee, Sir, This is the Perſon whom I recommend to your skill

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I receive this favour, with a great deal of ſatisfaction, this is an honour beyond expectation, I could not hope for ſuch an Illuſtrious Limner.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: If I had no skill at all, ſo beautiful a Perſon would inſpire me.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I rather need all the Favour your Pencil can afford; your excellent Skill muſt hide the faults and defects of Nature.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Nature, Madam, has not committed one, the Pencil muſt for ever deſpair of.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Come, enough of this, if you pleaſe, Sir, let alone theſe Compliments, and to your buſineſs, this is not at all to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: If pour Pencil, Sir, flatters, as much as your Tongue, the Picture you will draw, will not at all reſemble me.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Heaven that made the Original, has taken away all means of Flattery.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Heaven that made?—

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: I ſay, I will have no more Compliments, come, Sir, if you pleaſe, begin your Work.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I am ready.
sp.stage: (Pulls out his Pencils, Colours, and Palate.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Where ſhall I place my ſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Here Madam, this place receives the Light, beſt of any we ſhall find.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Do I ſit right?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Indifferent, Madam, a little more upright, if you pleaſe, a little more this way, your Body turn'd thus, lift up your Head, that the Beauty of your Neck may appear—your Breaſt bare, thus— (Goes, and feels her Breaſt. very well, a little more—more yet—

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: What a Pudder is here? I do not like all this, cannot you ſit as you ſhould.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: This is all new to me, I never ſate before, 'tis the Gentlemans buſineſs to place me, let him ſet me how he will.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: You ſit admirable well, Madam, keep your ſelf thus.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: So, Sir, pray to your Seat.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: A little more towards me, Madam? your Eye's always on me, I beſeech you, Madam, your Looks fixt to me.

sp.speaker: Betty:
sp.p: Now, Sir, pray do not flatter me, I am none of thoſe Women, who, if Pictures be but handſome, they care not whether they be like or no; one fine handſom Picture might ſerve 'em all, for all demand the ſame things, fine Features, and delicate Complexion; for my part, I deſire no Charity at all, let my Picture be but like, and I deſire no more.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
You are ſo rich in Beauty, that the Pencil can add nothing to you, it may poſſibly detract, it cannot flatter; ah, what ſweetneſs is there? what Charms, I undertake a bold Work, to repreſent thoſe Perfections. (Talks and Paints: I remember a ſtory of Apelles, Apelles once drew the Picture of a Miſtriſs of Alexander the Great, and as he was Painting her,
fell ſo paſſionately in Love with her, that he was ready to dye Alexander, out of pure Generoſity, beſtowed her upon him; I could not do as Apelles did, but ay, my Lord, I am afraid your Lordſhip will not prove an Alexander the Great.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Come, Sir, I pray proceed in your Painting, we have neither of us any buſineſs with Alexander the Great, that I know of.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: If Alexander the Great were by, he ſhould not hinder me from ſaying, I never ſaw any thing ſo charming, ſo—

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Sir, in plain terms, you talk too much, in my opinion, and do not at all mind your Pencil.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Lord, on the contrary, I diſcourſe out of regard to my Pencil? to quicken the Spirits, and put a Briskneſs and Gaiety in the Face.
sp.stage: Enter Merry, running dreſt like an Attorney, with a Green Bag under his Arm.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: How now, what would this fellow have? who let him in without my acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I beg your Lordſhips pardon for my rude preſſing in, I am unknown to your Lordſhip, but I have buſineſs of extraordinary concern, to your Lordſhip, which I muſt acquaint you of, with all ſpeed.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Buſineſs of extraordinary concern to me, what is it?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I muſt impart it to your Lordſhip in private.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: We are private enough here, I wont go out of the Room, for I don't like this Picture-Drawer.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Look you my Lord; ay, this Draws him aſide, and whiſpers, and produces ſeveral long ſcrowls. is it, no; this is not it; ay, this is it, no, no, ay, now I come to it.
sp.stage: Ramble ſtarts from his ſeat, and falls on his knees before Betty, watching L. Drybone ſtill.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: I would thou wert come to it once.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
Oh, charming Creature, if you have any pity in your Soul, ſave the life of a poor languiſhing Lover, that has been dying for you theſe two moneths, I have expreſſed my Love to you by Signs, and you have regarded them, and now I have ſtudied this way, to tell you in more intelligible manner; how much I Love, Admire, Adore you, above all the Creatures of the World above all I can expreſs, and ſhall, as
long as I live; but that life will not exceed this minute, if you put me not inſtantly out of diſpair.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I know you, Sir, I have obſerv'd you, (I confeſs) and do further acknowledge, your Love is not unpleaſing to me, but it is impoſſible for me to give you any ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: If you ſay the word, it is, and ſhall be poſſible, nay, it ſhall be impoſſible to hinder it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But, Sir, I am a cloſe Priſoner: and cannot ſtir out to ſave my own life, and much leſs yours.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Now you ſpeak unkindly for I have ſeen you abroad.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: It may be ſo, but like a Priſoner in the Kings Bench, never without my Keeper.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: You can ſhake off your Keeper, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: My Lord and I now, are upon pretty good terms; where do you lodge?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: At the Braziers in the Mall.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Be within about Two in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Divine Creature.

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: But hope for nothing but a Viſit, for there will be more words to a bargain, than theſe; I will have a farther tryal of Love, and I will have a better Love, than perhaps you intend.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh, Heavenly Creature, you ſhall have as much as you can hold.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: How now Mr. Painter, what are you doing there?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Is this a Mole, Madam, or a litle ſpeck of Dirt.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: A Mole, Madam, I Gad, this ſame Picture-Drawer.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Now my Lord, if the Conveighances be Drawn thus.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Prethee ha done with thy Conveighances, for I do not underſtand one word thou ſayſt.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: No my Lord, look you, I'll make it plain.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Well, if thou makeſt it never ſo plain, what is all this to me?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Not to you, my Lord, why are not you my Lord Buck?

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: No, nor my Lord Doe neither.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: What a Raskal was the Porter, to tell me, this wa • the Lord Bucks.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: What a Raskal was you, ſirrah, to come to troubl •

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Begone, my Lord's jealous. (Exit Merry. and grows into Choller; if he grows out of humour, our Plot's ſpoil'd.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Well Madam, enough for once.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and too much.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: To morrow I will wait on you again.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: I ſhall deſire your Pardon, you have done enough, too much at this time, to come here any more.

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: How, no more; what ſhall he not finiſh my Picture?

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: You mean my Picture, 'tis you that ſit, but 'tis my Picture that muſt be Drawn, and in an ugly ſhape too.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: How now, what is this noiſe, fye, my Lord Drybone, out upon thee, wilt thou never let this poor Creature have any reſt; I ſwear, I wonder ſhe will live with thee; what's the matter, Frisky?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Here's a noble Gentleman, has done me the honor to begin my Picture, and my Lord turns him away uncivilly, and won't let him compleat his Work.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: I know what Work you would have him compleat; ſtay, let me ſee; I will make an experiment, ſhew me your Work before you go, let me ſee how I like it.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Alaſs, my Lord, at preſent it is but rude, you can ſee nothing; four days hence, ſomething will appear.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Let me ſee it as it is, Sir; Ramble gives him the Picture. what a Devil of a Face is this?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Alaſs, it is but—but—a Pox on me for not looking on ſome Book, to get the terms— (Aſide. it is but departed Colours.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Departed Colours, what are thoſe? dead Colours, you would ſay, I believe.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, dead Colours, the other is a term Gentlemen uſe.

sp.speaker: L. Dry
sp.p: Ay, ſuch a Gentleman as you are; but Sir, can this ever be a Face?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: A moſt beautiful one, when my Pencil has lickt it.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Lickt it, ay indeed, it is more like a Bears Cubb, than a Face.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: It is a way of Drawing I have.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p:
Is it, Sir, pray if you pleaſe, let that door be your
way at preſent, and pray let my Houſe be never in your way of Drawing any more;—come in Betty, I'le talk with Draw-well for this trick.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: This Gentleman a Picture-Drawer? I ſwear he is the handſomeſt Picture-Drawer that ever I ſaw. Hold, Sir, pray, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Madam, I am commanded hence.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Sir, I have Empire enough here, to Reprieve you, at leaſt for a moment, and you ſhall ſtay, Sir, I underſtand, you Draw Pictures, and ſo handſome a Picture-Drawer, muſt needs draw very handſome Pictures, what ever my Lord Drybone ſays.

sp.speaker: Ramble.
sp.p: When I Draw yours, Madam, I cannot do otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: I ſwear, an incomparable well bred Man; Noble Sir, you have Drawn your own Portraicture, in moſt Gentile Colours, that I am extreamly ambitious; to have mine Drawn, by ſo delicate a hand.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Madam, my Hand is unworthy of that Honor, your Picture deſerves rather, to be Drawn in a Coach and Six Horſes, in Triumph round the Town.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: I ſwear, that is very witty, and ſurprizing—Sir, you now more and more inflame me, with an Ardent deſire to taſte of your skill; I will not reſt, till obtain the Felicity.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Pencil will be proud of the Glory—how ſhall I be rid of this impertinent Woman?

sp.speaker: Siſs.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady is extreamly troubled, and aſhamed, my Lord has Treated you thus uncivilly; by good luck, my Lord is juſt now call'd out, about an extraordinary affair, and will not be back theſe three hours: ſhe ſo extreamly deſires to have her Picture drawn. by you, that if you will ſtep down, ſhe will meet you at the door, and go and ſit for an hour in any place, you ſhall think convenient.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
Moſt excellent Creature, I adore thee for thy Meſſage, were I on a Precipiece, I would leap down to ſuch an invitation; I will diſintangle my ſelf, from Madam Impertinence, that hooks her ſelf to me, and be at the door in an inſtant, Madam, an affair of conſequence calls me away, Exit Siſs. my Pencils, my Oiſterſhells, my brighteſt Colours, the exacteſt
motion of my Hand, and the beſt of my skill, ſhall always attend your fair Phiſiognomy; Your Ladyſhips moſt humble Servant, and Picture-Drawer.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: The Top, the Cream, the Flower, the Quinteſcence, of Wit and Ingenuity; his harmonious Tongue, has left a tang, a reliſh of a Paſſion behind it; I ſwear, I feel a little Palpitation, I ſhall not be at repoſe, till I commence my Intrigue; and oh my brutiſh and obtuſe memory, I have forgot to ask him, what happy place he honours with his abode; but now I think on't, Frisky can lend me the knowledge, I will run with ſpeed, and borrow it of her.
sp.stage: Enter Ramble, and Betty Frisque, Vizarded.
The Scene, the Street, before Rambles Lodging.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Heaven be prais'd, we are ſafe at the place of Battle; this is my Lodging, in, in my Dear—my Sweet—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, I have honourably walk'd with you into the Field, but now I'le Article with you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I abhor the word, it has been lately miſchievous to me, and I will not hear it.
sp.stage: Enter a Woman Vizarded, as out of Ramb. Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Ramble; are you come, I have been waiting for my Picture this hour.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh curſe on my memory, I forgot this Aſſignation; I have ſuch bundles of Billets, Doux, that I muſt keep a Clark to enter them in a Journal, Dear Madam, I beg your pardon, I was pre-ingag'd to a Perſon of Honor, and I quite forgot, come an hour hence, and I will not fail you.
sp.stage: Enter to them a Second Woman.

sp.speaker: Se. Wo.
sp.p: So Mr. Ramble, you ſerve me finely, I have been ſtaying for my Picture theſe two hours, and here you promiſe 'em to Flirts, here is a Flirt newly gone out, has kept me priſoner in a Cloſet this hour, I was ſo fraid to be ſeen, for fear of my Honour.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: 2 Wo.
sp.p: No, Sir, I ſcorn to fit, if you draw the Pictures of every Flirt.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: So, Sir, but oh, I am ruin'd, my Lady Faddle's coming, whither ſhall I run, ſhe will know me by my Clothes.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: In—in—dear Madam, Betty and Ramble ſtrive to run in, Betty gets in, but La. Faddle catches Ramble. this Diſeaſe has faſten'd on me; how ſhall I be cur'd of her? what an unlucky Rogue am I in my Amours?

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Have I found you, Sir? this is fortunate, I will not part with you, till I obtain the Glory to be decipher'd by your ingenious hand.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, what Apelles is fit for ſo great a Work? you are ſo admirably Painted.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Not at all, Sir, you are miſinform'd, I onely uſe a little Red, Fo, Painted, I ſwear, I hate a Painted Woman in my heart, I ſuſpect their Virtue, beſides, 'tis naſty! Painted Fo.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I mean, by Natures Hand.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon, I miſunderſtood you.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: That Art were ſaucy to contend.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, you put me in a longing expectation; I beſeech you, let us to ſome convenient place, where you may begin your Work; put me in any poſture you pleaſe, ſweet Sir, and let me taſte plentifully of your skill.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Madam, I want ſome Poet to aſſiſt my Fancy, you ſhall be Drawn in a Triumphant Poſture, with all the Gods and Goddeſſes attending, Venus crying for not being ſo handſome, Juno ſcolding for jealouſie of you; blind Cupid borrowing Glaſs-Eyes, to ſtare on you; Jupiter transforming himſelf into a Lap-Dog, to kiſs you; Mars lying naked under your Feet, in the ſhape of a Backſword.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Oh, admirable, when ſhall this moſt rare Peece be begun?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: That, Madam, I do not know.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Not know, Sir, Why? Sir, is it not your own Noble Hand performs it?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Hand will not have the Glory.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Whoſe then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I do not know, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Sir, this is Superlative Modeſty; Come, come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Maſter, Sir—how, my Wife that muſt be, here?

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Oh, dear, my Servant here, I ſhall be diſhonoured, this is unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Does my Maſter deal with ſtale Fleſh too? and is he making me a Cuckold before I am married? I do not much care, he cannot cuckold me of her Money, how ſhall I do to out-face him now—how now, Jack Ramble, engroſs all the Ladies.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: What ſhall I Reply, what ſhall I Invent? this is Infernal

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: How now, ſirrah, how came you and I ſo familiar? what, is this thy Rogues Plot?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: So Madam, this is fine.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: I ſwear, Sir,—I ſwear—I don't know what to ſwear I am, in ſuch confuſion.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Very well, Madam; this is a good beginning.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: This Rogue is intimate with her.—This is ſome Plot, that I cannot diſcover. But ha, here is Sir Thomas coming this way in haſte.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Raſh catch me here? this is diſhonour upon diſhonour.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Raſh, and four Bayliffs.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: So, have I found you? that is the Lady, I Command you, take her.

sp.speaker: 1 Bay.
sp.p: Lady Faddle, I Arreſt you in the Kings name, in an Action of a Thouſand pounds, at the Suit of Sir Thomas Raſh, here preſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come, put in ſubſtantial Bayl, or go to Jayl.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: An Arreſt at my Lodging?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: My Wife that muſt be, Arreſted?

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Arreſted?
sp.stage: Ramble and Merry offer to Draw, and the Bayliffs ſtep in, and diſarm them.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, be not too forward, your turn will come ſoon enough.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Is this done, Sir Thomas, like a Civil Perſon, and a Perſon of Honour?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: What is the buſineſs, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: I will declare before all theſe Gentlemen; Know then, that a Nephew of mine; a Baronet in the Countrey, was bound in a Bond of a thouſand pounds to come up to Town, and Marry Mrs. Chriſtina, Sir Thomas's Daughter, four days ago, and I was bound in the ſame Bond.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: And my Nephw failing to come up, Sir Thomas, like an uncivil perſon, takes the forfeiture of the Bond.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: How, Sir Thomas, have you ingag'd your Daughter to any one, after you have promis'd her to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I promis'd her to you, to be your Strumpet, did I?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: My Strumpet! ſure, Sir Thomas you are craz'd, I know not what you mean, nor do you know your own meaning.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: That ſhall be try'd.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Is this all the buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho,
sp.p: Come Bayliffs, with your Priſoner to the Jayl.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, I'll releaſe her; Madam, we will have a trick for his trick, ſay you are my Wife, and plead Covert-Bearn.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Was this the Rogues Plot? he has gull'd this ſimple Lady into Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſhe is the Wife of me, John Merry, Eſq, of Merry-Hall, now, meddle with her, Sir, if you dare.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir, are you come over me ſo? very well; then I ſhall ſpeedily take out a Writ to Arreſt John Merry, Eſq, in an Action of a Thouſand pounds, and he ſhall pay it me every farthing, if all the Eſtate, the ſaid John Merry and his Wife, the late Dame Faddle, have in the World, can pay it.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Sir Thomas, I would have you to know that, do your worſt, my Eſtate is able to pay twice that ſum, yet I have enough remaining.

sp.speaker: Merry,
sp.p: I am glad to hear of that, 3 or 4 thouſand pounds will be good Sauce to make the old Gooſe go down.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Hold! before this noble Company part I have ſomething of great importance to ſay to Mr. Ramble, in the Preſence of you all, Sir, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Sir, I am your unfortunate Daughter. (Kneels to Sir Tho. who, in obedience to your Commands, am going to remove ſo great a misfortune as my ſelf, for ever from your Family; but e'r I depart, I beg of you, by all your paſt Fatherly Love, by the ſecret remains of it ſtill in your Breaſt; by the Remembrance of my dear Mother, in Heaven, to give me leave to vindicate my ſelf, and challenge this baſe Villain, in the Preſence of Heaven, who knows my Innocence in your own Preſence, to whom he has wrong'd me, in the Preſence of all theſe, to affirm, if he dares, if there be any truth, or ſhaddow of truth, in any Word or Tittle, of what he ſpoke, in prejudice of my Honour.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Hey, what Miſtery? what Riddle? what Dream is this?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, now affirm to her face, what you ſaid of her laſt night; that ſhe had been naught with you before, that ſhe had made an appointment then to be naught with you, and that ſhe had been naught before ever you touch'd her.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh horrid! what Devil has forg'd ſuch an abominable falſhood, of me; May Heaven ſtrike me dead with Thunder; may the Earth ſink and ſwallow me; may all the Curſes of injured Innocence purſue me; if ever ſuch an impious thought came into my ſoul.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Oh Impudence, Impudence.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: And to ſhow my Words and Thoughts are the ſame, I here declare her, as pure and ſpotleſs, as a Soul in Heaven. I deſire no greater happineſs in the World, than to poſſeſs her with all thoſe misfortunes; which I am accus'd to have brought upon her.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Was ever the like impudence heard? he ſaid all this, I charge him with, to my face, and fought with me to maintain his words.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Very well, I ſhall have nothing to do with you, or your diſputes; know my Nephew is come to Town; but he ſhall go back again, and break off the Match, and ſo take your courſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Sir Mannerly, come? hold, Madam, one word more with your Ladyſhip, and I'll end all controverſies: Well, Mr. Ramble, you declare in the Preſence of my Lady Faddle, and us all, that you never meant the words you ſaid.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: That I never ſaid or thought any thing of this Lady, but what a Votary might ſay of the Saint he prays to.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: That you acknowledge her intirely innocent of—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: That her Innocence is equal with her Beauty; and that her Beauty can be equall'd by nothing, but her own Innocence; and that ſhe can be compar'd with none, but her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: And that you will marry her, when ever I pleaſe. and leave her Fortune to my diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: That I will marry her, without any conſideration of a Fortune, rather than any other Woman in the World, with a Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Very well, then take notice, I will marry her to Sir Mannerly Shallow; and ſo my Lady Faddle, I releaſe your Ladyſhip, and now our Conteſt is ended.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.p: Hold, Mr. Ramble, do not dare to interpoſe, my Father has declar'd his Pleaſure, and I declare my ready obedience; however, I will never have you of all Men.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Oh my torment!

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Well, Sir Thomas, you have dealt (let me tell you) ungentilely with me; but however, to put an end to controverſies, I forgive you, and ſo let the Match proceed.
sp.stage: (Exit Sir Tho. Raſh, La. Fad. Chr. and Iſab.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Merry, a word, is this Lady your Wife?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Yes, in earneſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then, ſirrah, make her break off this Match, or I'll cut your Throat, how dear ſoever I pay for it.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Well, Sir, a word to the wiſe is enough, you may be ſure, I'll do what—lies in my power.—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: So ſo, Mr. Ramble, you are a very fine Man, ſome Women come to you for their Pictures, and others for promiſe of Marriage; I have heard all paſſages, this is you that Lov'd, Admir'd, Adored me above all Creatures in the World; above all you could expreſs; that you could have no Reſt, day nor night, for thinking and ſighing after me: poor loving Man; I had been ſweetly ſerv'd, if I had been ſuch a fool, as to have believ'd you, and fall'n a loving you, as hard as ever I could drive: well, I thank you, you have done me a kindneſs, I ſhall endure my confinement a little better after this: nay, I ſhall thank my old Lord, for keeping me out of the Temptations of ſuch falſe diſſembling inſinuating Men.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: So, ſo, forſaken, and hated by every one, all Afflictions come together; I am juſtly ſerv'd for my liquoriſh, greedy, inſatiable, ridiculous Temper; that like Adam, could not be contented in Paradiſe, but muſt be taſting all ſorts of Fruit, lawful or unlawful, though I had pleaſures enow in Chriſtinas Love, to ſatisfy a Demy-God, and more than any meer creature could merit; well, diſpair ſhall be damn'd, before he ſhall have the fingering of me yet,—opportunity has not ſo turn'd his bald Crown on me; but I can have hold enough of his Ears yet, at leaſt, I will have hold of my Rival's Ears, who e'r he be; this ſhall give him to underſtand; (Shows his Sword.) what Portion he ſhall have with his Lady; nay, what Lady he ſhall have, for this fair ſlender Creature ſhall injoy his Body, and ſpeedily

div.head: SCENE The Street, Sir Mannerly dreſt in a fine Countrey-faſhion'd Suit.
div.stage: Enter Sir Mannerly, Shallow, and Booby.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: HOW do my Cloaths become me, Booby.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Bravely, an't like your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: And am I pretty handſome.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: I never ſee a handſomer Man peep out of a Suit of Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Well, I long for my Bride, oh how gentilely could I ſalute her now? Madam, what a Spring, a Source, a Fountain, a River of Love and Beauty flows from your eyes; a Nilus of Beauty overflows the Aegypt of your Face.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Raſh, nor Madam Chriſtina, are no where to be found, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Hey, not to be found? well, then there is knavery in this, they do it on purpoſe to make me forfeit my Bond. Oh dear, here comes the perſon of Quality Enter the Porter. I invited to my Wedding, what ſhall I ſay to excuſe my ſelf to him?—Noble Sir, I ſwear I am ſo out of Aſpect—I know not how to demean my ſelf, I was ſo bold as to crave the honor of your company, at my Wedding Supper to night, and I ſwear, Sir, I cannot find my Bride—

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Not find your Bride, Sir? that's ſtrange; it's a common thing here in London for Women to run away from their Husbands after they'r Married, but I never knew a Woman run from her Husband before ſhe was Married, till now, well Sir, there's no hurt done.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p:
Hold, noble Sir, I have receiv'd ſo many noble Favours from you to day, that I will not let you ſtir, till I know to whom I am ſo much oblig'd—that I may know to whom to repay; I beſeech you, Sir, to let me know your
Honourable name, for I am ſure you are of Noble Quality.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, I am a Knight,—I was dubbed 〈◊〉 Lord Mayors ſhew.—

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Look you there, Booby, did not I ſay he was a Knight? I beſeech you, Sir, of what Order? for by your Silver Chain, and noble Silver Plate, you muſt be of ſome Order, that I have not read of in Heraldry.
