sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: I am of a very old Order, Sir, of the Order of Iſacher. I ſtoop under my burden, and my Creſt is an Aſs Couchant.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Look you there, Booby; I beſeech you, Sir, your Name.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: My Name is Raſh, Sir, at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: What—not Sir Thomas Raſh?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Old Tom Raſh,—Sir Thomas, if you will have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh ſtrange, Booby.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Raſh's Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Did one ever ſee the like? here have I been Angling and Trowling for my Father-in-law, and have had him at my Hook all day.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: This is juſt as your Worſhip and I, lookt up and down for your Boots one day, and you had 'em on your Legs.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Juſt ſo for all the World.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: What have I done now, I am afraid I have brought more Compliments on my Head—they come—they come full ſwinge—oh, what will become of me? oh, Sir, have mercy on me.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Noble Father-in-law.
sp.stage: (Sir Man. and Booby, run and embrace him.)

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: His Worſhips Father-in-law's Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: What do they call me Father-in-law?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Your Worſhip, Sir Thomas, I believe, does not know my Maſters Worſhip; my Maſters Worſhip, is Sir Mannerly Shallow; that is come to Town, according to his Bond, to marry your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Come to Town to marry my Daughter? I begin to think 'em merry Men again; let me be hang'd if I can gueſs, whether they be fools, or no, for my life;—I facks, I rather think they make a fool of me.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I am the ſame Sir Mannerly Shallow, on my Honor Sir.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Sir Mannerly Shallow, ha-ha, what comes in my Head (Laughs.) I heard my Maſter, and Name-ſake, Sir Thomas Raſh, talk of one Sir Mannerly Shallow; that is to Marry my young Lady, and I warrant, this ſimple Gentleman is he; and he hearing my name to be Thomas Raſh, and calling my ſelf in waggery, Sir Thomas,—he takes me to be my Maſter: ha—ha—ha.—
Hark you Maſter, are not you Sir Mannerly Shallow?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I am, on my Honor, Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Ha-ha-ha.—

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Ay, the ſame; ha-ha-ha.—

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: It is his Worſhip.—
sp.stage: They all three laugh, and the Porter laughs the more, to ſee them laugh.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: I have laugh'd my Heart ſore; what a knaviſh prank could I play now, to paſs for Sir Thomas Raſh, and pop my Daughter on this ſilly Knight: well, Sir, I will not cheat you, I am honeſt Tom Raſh, a poor Porter, and Servant, to that very Sir Thomas Raſh you want, and come along, I'le lead you to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Come, Father-in-Law, this is not gentile; now you have owned your ſelf, to deny your ſelf again; you do it, now you ſee who I am, to make me forfeit my Bond—but what have I diſcover'd? Let me compare the very ſame Coat of Arms: I ſwear, this was well thought Pulls out a Letter, and compares the Seal with the Arms of the Porters Badge. on; Ile take my Oath; now if you deny your ſelf, Ile go to Law with you, for I know you by your Arms.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: This is better and better, ha-ha-ha,—

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: My Father-in-Law, I ſee is a merry Man—

sp.speaker: Boob,
sp.p: Sir Thomas, his Worſhip did but jeſt.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Well, I • ll own my ſelf to be Sir Thomas Raſh, carry him to my Cellar, and there let my Wife look to him, whilſt I call my Maſter—Come, Son-in-Law, I am your Father-in-Law; and I am heartily glad to ſee you; I'll conduct you to my Off-Spring, and your Bed-Mate, that muſt be—what ſport is here?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Did not I ſay 'twas he?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: What luck was this to find him, juſt as your Bond was forfeited.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Ay, and by the Coat of Arms,—you muſt know, I am very well skill'd in Coats of Arms—I can tell all our own Coats, and all the Quarterings, ever ſince King Cadwallader. Oh, but Booby, was it not pretty, that I ſhould invite my Father-in-law, to his own Daughters Wedding.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: I warrant, that made his Worſhip laugh ſo heartily.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Well thought on, I ſwear, now run to my Cloakbag, and fetch my bag of Money, to pay for my Wedding Dinner.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: I ſhall, an't like your Worſhip.—

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Sir, am not I a loving Servant, that forſake the Wife of my Boſom; now Love has Cook'd, and Diſh'd her up, and leave her piping hot, to run after your Appetite.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Thou art an honeſt fellow, Merry; but all things conſider'd, the kindneſs is as great to thy ſelf, as me, however, I accept it—but haſt thou hunted out my Rival?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: I ſaw him here about, not a quarter of an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What a kind of fellow is he.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis ſuch a Cumberland Piece, he is much farther from underſtanding, than his Countrey is from London; and has ſuch a living Log follows him, as you never ſaw:—many a wiſer Block has ſuffer'd Martyrdom for Chriſtmas, in his Maſters Hall Chimney.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Prethee lets inquire here about for them, by thy deſcription, they are ſo Remarkable, every body that has ſeen 'em, will inform us of them.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: How, are you mad, Thomas, looſe ſuch a Fortune for my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: What, ſhall I play the knave o'that faſhion?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Is it knavery to own your Chriſtendom? is not your name Raſh? and were not you Chriſtned Thomas?

sp.speaker: Raſh,
sp.p: But I was not Chriſtned Sir Thomas, was I?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Well, if the Knight will Chriſten you Sir Thomas, what's that to any one?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: What, I ſhall ha my Maſter, Sir Thomas, ha me up, coram nobis, for Forgery.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Well let him him coram nobis you as much as he dares; there's no Law againſt owning ones own name; let him take his Silver Badge again, and he will, we can live without his Chain, we ſhall be as good as he now.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I tell you, I wont do it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Won't you? then let my Goods rot and they will, I'll ne'r ſell penny-worth of Apples or Gingerbread more, whilſt I live.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Theſe Women will rule the Roaſt—well, I'll be Sir Thomas then, but if I look through a Scotch Caſement for this, that is to ſay, a Pillory; I'll lodge a Cudgel in your middle Story backward.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Let them do what they dare, they ſhall find a Meſs of hot Codlings o'me, I warrant them; give me my clean Kercher, and my Hat, and run quickly, an fetch Winny from School.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: There, there, Don 'em quickly, our Son-in-Law comes.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Mannerly and Booby, with a bag of Money under his Arm, a Beggar-woman with a Child begging of Sir Mannerly.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Well, I never ſaw ſuch a fine ſtreet in my life.

sp.speaker: Beg. Wo.
sp.p: Pray your Worſhip, give a poor Woman ſomething.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Begone, Beggar-woman.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Son-in-law, you are heartily welcome; ſee, this is your Mother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: For want of a better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Madam, your moſt humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p:
Well, Son, I'll run and fetch your Bride, ſhe is but two doors off, at a Boarding-School, where I keep her for good
Breeding; you wonder to ſee ſo many Apples here; my Wife and I, you muſt know, are great lovers of Apples, and we are laying in our Winter Store, into our Cellar; that's my Cellar, but that great Houſe is my Habitation.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Oh Stately, that's like the Palace of Sol-ſublimibus, Alta Columnis:—And Gold on the top too, Clara micante Auro.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: I, to ſhow I love Apples, I have a Golden Apple, a Golden Pippin on the top; well, I'll leave you with my Wife, I'll be back preſently:—

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Is your Ladyſhip ſo great a lover of Apples? I ſhall agree with you then mightily in Diet, for I love Apples, as well as ever Adam did, and here are as many fine Apples, as ever I ſaw in all my life.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Curious Apples indeed.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray Son-in-law, be pleas'd to eat one, there's a Pippin as good a one, as ever Tooth was put in—and as ſound as my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: A pure Pippin.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhips moſt humble Servant; my Lady's a plain Woman, Booby.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: She ſeems a very hearty Woman, an't like your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: See, Son, here's your young Yoke-fellow, that muſt into the Nooſe with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: A moſt tranſcendent Beauty?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: A plain Girl.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Not at all, ſhe's the Epitome of Perfection; I am enamour'd above the capacity of expreſſion; I deſerve to forfeit a thouſand Bonds of a thouſand pound, for ſtaying the thouſandth part of a minute, from her Imbraces; I will pay the forfeiture of my Bond in Love and Kiſſes;—I will number up:

sp.speaker: Beg. Wo.
sp.p: Pray good your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Man,
sp.p: What a troubleſome Woman art thou? doſt not ſee I am buſy a Complimenting?—I ſay, I will number up by Art Arithmetical

sp.speaker: Beg. Wo.
sp.p: Pray your Worſhip,

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Did one ever ſee the like?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Woman, do not trouble his Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Begone, or I'll ſend for the Beadle.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I ſay, I will number up—I will number up—this ſcurvy Beggar-Woman has broke off my Speech, that I vow and ſwear, I do not know what I was going to ſay—I had better ha given her a ſhilling, than have loſt ſuch a Speech.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: I could find in my heart, Beggar-Woman to kick you, for ſpoiling his Worſhips Speech—no matter—your Worſhip—has twenty more as good.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: No matter for Compliments, come Son-in-law, to Church, if you pleaſe, and there let the Parſon complement you both into Man and Wife, and that's the Compliment of Compliments.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: With all my heart, and may a thouſand Cupids hover over every Pue, to fill your heart as full of Love, as mine is of Love and Admiration.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Did you ever hear ſuch pure Compliments?

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Never in all my days.
sp.stage: (As they are going off, Enter Ramble and Merry.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: That's he.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Is that he, 'tis ſo ridiculous a fellow, I cannot be angry with him?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Go, Sir, Manage him—whilſt I handle Log, the Second King of Frogs, that follows him.
sp.stage: Ramble takes Sir Mannerly, and Merry, Booby, aſide.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Sir, one word with you in private.—To Sir Man.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Sir, one word with you in private.—To Booby.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: With me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: With me forfooth?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, it muſt be very private.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Ay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Is not your name Sir Mannerly Shallow?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: It is, Sir, what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Are not you come to Town to marry Sir Thomas Raſh's Daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I am, Sir, what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Four Oxen to run for a Wager, Sir, do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: From Tweed to Newcaſtle.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then you muſt not have her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: How, not have her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No ſtirring, Sir, if you do, this runs into your Guts.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Into my Guts, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, into your Guts, Sir.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: My Maſters Py'd Ox to be one.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: For a wager of Fourſcore Load of Hay—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No Booby, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: No Booby, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: No Booby, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: To be eat all with Muſtard.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: All with Muſtard?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: An Ox eat Muſtard!

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: All with Muſtard!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I ſhall be very brief with you, I ſhall propound but two things to you, take your choiſe, either to go out immediately, and fight me, and he of us too, that comes alive out of the Field, ſhall have the Lady; or elſe this minute to take Poſt for Cumberland, and not to come up, till I am married to her.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: To go out and fight with you, Sir!

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, till one of us fall dead, or ride Poſt for Cumberland; take your choice.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Ride Poſt for Cumberland, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, chuſe inſtantly, or this goes into your Guts, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: My Guts, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Ay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No Booby, Sir; ſpeak quickly what you'll do:

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: And the Ox that wins, to be Knighted.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: To be Knighted?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: I never heard the like; let me tell his Worſhip—

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Preſently, when I ha done:—I have not half done.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Say what you'll do, and that inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Sir, I'll.—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What will you do, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Sir, I'll.—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Diſpatch, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Sir, I'll—Sir, I will not, Sir! What ha you to do to make me fight? or ride Poſt either? whether I will or no, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: No queſtioning my Authority, ſpeak inſtantly, I ſay inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: I never met with ſuch a fellow in my life.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: You will not ſpeak, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Sir, I'll.—

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Sir, I'll ride Poſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then come along, Sir;—I'll ſee you mounted—and attend you, or one ſhall for me; one forty or fifty miles on the way, no looking o'r your Shoulder, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Mr. Booby, Mr. Booby. there's a Gentleman runs away with your Maſter, call a Conſtable, Thomas, a Conſtable, come along with me Winny to call a Conſtable.
sp.stage: Drags him out, Sir Mannerly looks back, and offers to ſpeak, Ramble ſtops his mouth.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Is the Woman mad to make a Hubbub?—hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I will not, he carries away our Son-in-law by force.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: One ſteal my Maſter!

sp.speaker: Mrery.
sp.p: No ſtirring, Sir.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: No ſtirring—What you help to ſteal him, do you? here Beggar-woman, hold my Bag of Money a little, and I'll try a friskin with him, thou ſhalt not come at thy Sword, Man.
sp.stage: Gives the Beggar woman, the Bag of Money to hold.
(Merry and Booby fight off the Stage.
A noiſe of a Hubbub within, and mean while the Beggar-Woman watches her opportunity, lays down the Child, and runs away with the Money.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: This is good, the Conſtable and the Rabble have ſeiz'd our Foes; and we the Aggreſſors have eſcap'd, whilſt the two Clowns ſtick faſt in the Mudd of the dirty Crowd; Let's purſue our fortunes, overtake Sir Thomas, and the company, be very impudent and obſtinate, and ſee what that will do.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir,—for I do not care for coming within the reach of that heavy fiſted fool any more.
sp.stage: Enter Conſtable, Sir Mannerly, Booby, Raſh, Wife, and Winnifrid.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: You have let go the Thieves that would have ſtolen me, and here you hold my Man and me.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Stolen you, Sir? I found this man in actual Battery.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: He batter'd me as much.

sp.speaker: Raſh.
sp.p: Come, come, Son-in-law, never make a buſtle on your Wedding-day, give the Conſtable a ſpill.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: There's a ſpill, but I take my Oath he would have ſtolen me.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: No more words on't, come—there, go about your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Come, Madam, as the Poet ſays—Per varios caſus per tot diſcrimina rerum. Exeunt. Sir Man. Raſh, Wife, and Win.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: I think I plough'd his chops for him; an he had cuff'd a little longer, I would ha pull'd up his Noſe by the Roots—but where's the Beggar-woman with my bag of Money? look if ſhe has not laid it in the Street, like a baggage, a thouſand to one, but it might have been ſtolen—hey, my bag of Money is alive? a Baſtard, a Baſtard, (Takes up the Child. ſtop Thief, ſtop Thief? a Beggar-woman has run away with a bag of Money, and has left a Baſtard in the room; ſtop Thief, Thief.
sp.stage: (Lays down the Child, and offers to run away.

sp.speaker: Watch-m.
sp.p: Mr. Conſtable, Mr. Conſtable, here's a fellow has lain a Child in the Street.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Stop him, ſtop him, knock him down; how now, ſirrah, lay a Baſtard in the Street!

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Is it my Baſtard? is it not the Beggar-womans Baſtard, that was a begging here? and has run away with all my Money?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: She was your Whore, was ſhe, ſirrah? here's a fine Plot of a Rogue, neighbors; to make a buſtle in the Streets, that his Whore might have an opportunity to lay a Baſtard to the Pariſh: yes, ſirrah, the Pariſh ſhall maintain ſuch a luſty Rogue as you in Lechery?—come, ſirrah, to the Houſe of Correction.

sp.speaker: Watch-m.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Conſtable, whip him, whip him, this way the Pariſh-money goes; I have been ſeſs'd above Fifteen ſhillings this year, for ſuch Rogues unlawful Lecheries.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Whip me! I never ſaw the Woman before in my life.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Then you lay with her in the dark, did you ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: I am but newly come to Town.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Then you ſhall be whipt aſſoon as you come; a Whipping-Poſt ſhall be your welcome.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Whip me if you dare, ſince you go to that, for I belong to a Critique.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: A Critique, What's that?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: A great Judge, that was he that was here juſt now.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: He a Judge? he looks like a Man fit to hold the Scale of Juſtice indeed; he is more fit to hold a Grocers Scale; and weigh Plums and Comfits, then Cauſes.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Come, ſirrah, I'll let out your hot Bloud, I'll Plant a Grove o'Birch in your Arſe o'peak.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Conſtable, my Maſter is a Northern Judge, indeed, and a Baronet, I can prove it.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: I care not what he is, ſirrah; will he put in ſecurity to keep the Child, and buy off your Whipping?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Why muſt he? or muſt I be whipt?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: That, Time ſhall try.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Conſtable, come along; my Maſters Worſhip ſhall be bound, and give you any content.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Well, let's ſee what he will do.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Tho. Raſh, Merry, Chriſtina, La. Faddle, Iſabella, Bridget, and Ramble.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Where have you been Mr. Merry?

sp.speaker: Merry,
sp.p: Onely ſetling ſome things about my Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Do not follow, and Tantany us, Mr. Ramble, for I declare poſitively, thou ſhalt never have my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Mr. Ramble, my Father is ingag'd to another, but whether he was, or no, the words you ſaid, are never to be forgiven, neither Extravagance, Railery, Drink, nor nothing can excuſe 'em, they have fix'd you in my Eternal Hatred; and you are the onely thing of all Heavens Creatures, I abhor.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Then I am the onely wretched thing of the whole Creation, and the more wretched, ſince I ſuffer Innocently; for what ever have been my other ſins, from that unpardonable one, of Blaſpheming your Honor, I am wholly innocent, conſider why I ſhould ſay it, what ſhould move me to it; what did provoke me; and what ſhould I gain by it, when ſaid?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: That foppiſh vain Glory, which poſſeſſes all your Sex, of defaming thoſe Women, whoſe Honours you cannot otherwiſe abuſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why, Sir, what ſhould move me? what provoke me? and what ſhould I gain by telling a lye, Sir?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: I ſwear, Madam, I begin to pitty him, and think there's ſome miſtake.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: I dare not interpoſe, for fear of diſcovering the affair, about my Picture—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come, Sweet-heart, you are the chief Perſon concern'd; you muſt reſign your claim to this Lady—for Jack Ramble is my friend, and though I know nothing of the buſineſs, I know he is Innocent, becauſe I know him to be an honeſt fellow; but whether innocent or no, I will have Matters made up; for in plain terms, if my friend may not Bed the Woman, he loves, I will not Bed the Woman I love; I will never be happy, while my friend is miſerable.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: How, Mr. Merry?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Let me alone with him, Madam; Sir, what have you to do to intermeddle in my affairs; Bed who you will, Sir, and what you will, Sir; but if you ſay, he did not ſay theſe words, I give you the Lye, and there's my Glove.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Take your Glove, Sir, your Hand is old, and will catch cold.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Some Devil has appear'd to him in my ſhape, and ſaid this.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh dear, have I met with your Ladyſhip? (To La. Fad.) this is lucky, if ever you will be kind to me in your life, Madam, take me into your company—I have been abroad but two hours, and my Lord has been to ſeek me in ſuch a rage, that if you do not excuſe me, it will be a parting quarrel.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Betty Frisque here? how do my ſins follow me? what ſhall I do? now I think on't, ſhe dares no more own the knowledge of me, then I dare of her: my ſtanding vertue, Impudence, muſt aid me

sp.speaker: La. Fad
sp.p: Why doſt thou do this, Betty?

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: So Gentlewoman, are you hearded?—ha, what do I ſee here, her Father? that's he I ſaw laſt night; I'm ſure on't; I remember his Face again, though I ſaw him in the dark, very well, Sir, take your Daughter again, I am very glad 'tis you ſhe runs to, I thought to have found her in worſe company; there, Sir, take her, take her, and make the beſt of her.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: My Daughter, Sir; to whom do you ſpeak, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: What, more miſtakes?

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: To you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: To me, Sir? I am as good a man as your ſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: As good a man, Sir.

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Sir, I am a perſon of Honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: And I am a perſon of Quality, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p:
Well, Sir, be of what quality you will, Sir, you came laſt night to my door with Fiddles, and challeng'd me for debauching your Daughter, Sir, then you could own her
in the dark, for your own pleaſure, Sir; and now I will make you own her for mine; and as I told you laſt night, ſhe had been debauch'd, before I touch'd her; ſo I tell you again, if ſhe had not, perhaps I would have conſider'd her.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: The miſtake comes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hold, my Lord, was not you in your Night-gown and Drawers?

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and you was in a Buff Coat.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Mr. Ramble, where art thou, wilt thou forgive me? canſt thou forgive me? honeſt Mr. Ramble forgive me.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Now Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: My Lord, I thank you heartily for this diſcovery, you have clear'd up a miſtake, in which I perſiſted to the injury of an honeſt Gentleman; but now I will do my ſelf and him right; know then, this Gentleman is a Servant to my Daughter, and this is my Daughter I challeng'd you about, and finding him ſomething Airy and Wild, was deſirous to hinder the Match and he paſſing by my door with Fiddles laſt night I, in a rage, purſu'd him to your Lordſhips, and miſtaking your Lordſhip for him, in the dark, I challeng'd you with intentions of debauching my Daughter, and your Reply intangled us in difficulties, which now are vaniſh'd.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Then this is the Lady, it ſeems, was Serenaded.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: The ſame, my Lord, the Playing at your door was but a blind.—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No, no, 'twas to me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He brings himſelf off wittily.

sp.speaker: L. Dry,
sp.p: But hold, Sir, now I remember, you came to draw her Picture to day.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Has he that trick too?

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: I did ſo.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I have an Intrigue with him.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: But it was onely for divertiſement, I never ſaw her before in my life.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why do you ſay ſo? 'twas an appointment, well, my Lord, you and I muſt part, you ſee how falſe I am.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Dear Betty, forgive me, I ſee thou haſt more Vertue and Goodneſs, than I have Eſtate to Reward; live with me again, and I will become a new Creature.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: That muſt be by ſome very ſtrange miracle indeed, that an old Man ſhould become a new Creature—but however, mend as much as you will, I ſhall never mend, I ſhall continue my Intrigues with Picture-Drawers, and Pages, and Hackney-Coachmen—and every Man I can come near.—

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: Oh, do not Treat me thus ſeverely, I have injur'd thy Vertue, but I will make thee recompence for my life, and all the pleaſure of it lies in thy Favour.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No, no, this keeping of old Women, by you old Sinners, is but done out of a ſcurvy cuſtom, not any need you have: like old Snuff-takers, that cannot live without Snuff, though it never makes 'em ſneeze; do but break your ſelf of the cuſtom for one month, and you will find no want: but come, ſince you are humbled, I make a propoſal; Promiſe before all this noble Company, to make a ſettlement of 500 l. a year, on me for life, that if we ever quarrel, I may have ſomething to truſt to, and I will return to my Dominion again, and govern you as formerly.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: I engage it, and you ſhall have it drawn by what Lawyers you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Then I am yours in the new-faſhion'd Matrimony for ever.

sp.speaker: L. Dry.
sp.p: I am as formerly, your moſt obſequious Keeper.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Oh, theſe are fine doings, but I ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Now Madam, it is my turn to quarrel, and be unkind.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes indeed, you had need boaſt of your Innocence; witneſs the Importunate Temptations of a young Lady, which you manfully reſiſted laſt night, and could by no means be brought to her imbraces, witneſs this Creature, whoſe Picture it ſeems you drew, an Excellence I never knew you had till now.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p:
Oh, forgive me, I acknowledge my faults with grief and penitence, I am amazed, how it was poſſible for me to think of any thing but you, but hopes of Love, are like the proſpect of a fair Street, a great way off, and you cannot
blame a poor thirſty Traveller, if he takes a ſip here and there by the way—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: How on thy Knees Mr. Ramble? I ſwear, we rather ought to kneel to thee. Riſe, riſe, Man, were I not to forfeit a thouſand pound Bond, thou ſhouldſt have my Daughter before any Man.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir, Dirt ſhall never be laid in the Scale with Beauty, I will pay the forfeiture.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: This is brave, I ſwear, now Madam, you are bound in Honor and Gratitude to forgive him.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Mr, Ramble, this is ſo generous a Propoſition, that I will pay the forfeiture of the Bond, give thee my Daughter, and a Thouſand pound more, with her, than ever I deſign'd for her Portion, with any Man—take her—ſhe's thine.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I hope you will give over your Picture-Drawing.

sp.speaker: Ramb.
sp.p: Now I am in Heaven, and all my ſins forgiven, upbraid me not with them; I will Draw no Pictures but my own, and thoſe never without your help.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: How, Sir Thomas, will you uſe my Nephew thus ſcurvily?

sp.speaker: Merry.
sp.p: How, will you oppoſe my deſire? Reſiſt my Virgin authority.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Mr. Merry, I will not have my Nephew thus abus'd:
sp.stage: (Enter Sir Mannerly, Winnifrid, Porter, and Wife)
sp.p: See, he has found us.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: My Lady Aunt, wiſh me joy.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Wiſh thee joy, Sweet-heart, for what? for looſing thy Bride? here is Sir Thomas Raſh, after all our Articles, is going unworthily, to beſtow his Daughter upon another.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: How, Aunt? you do not know Sir Thomas Raſh when you ſee him, nor his Daughter neither—ſure I have her faſt enough, I am married to her already, and here ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: This the Creature that was deſign'd for me? bleſs me! what a deliverance have I had?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: This Sir Mannerly.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: What doſt thou ſay; art thou Married to that Girl?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Married to my Porters Daughter? this fellow is my Porter, Madam, and his Wife is my Apple-woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Your Porter, What's that?

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: He goes of Errands for Groats and Teſtors, and Pence, this is Sir Thomas Raſh, and this is his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: How! am I couzen'd ſo? is this Sir Thomas Raſh? and is this his Daughter?—are you no Sir Thomas, and you no my Lady, and do you go of Errands for Groats, and Pence? and do you ſell Apples?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: Faith Son, 'tis a folly to diſown it, now all is done; theſe are our Occupations, I am no Knight, but of your dubbing; you would dubb me a Knight, whether I would or no—I was not ambitious of the Honor.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Well, though we are poor folks, we are Honeſt and True.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Honeſt and True; ſirrah come back and Un-marry me again.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir Mannerly, now 'tis too late; how came this miſtake, Tom?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: My being your worſhips Nameſake, caus'd it, he would needs bear me down, I was your Honor, and Marry my Daughter, in ſpight of my Teeth.

sp.speaker: La. Fad.
sp.p: Oh, how haſt thou diſhonour'd our Family?

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Fear not, Aunt, I'll Feague 'em; Porter, I'll make it a ſcurvy Errand to you; and Apple-woman, your Daughter ſhall be a coſtly Pippin to you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Do your worſt.
sp.stage: Enter Conſtable and Booby, with a Child in his Arms.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Here's his Worſhip; oh an't like your Worſhip, ſhall if you won't be bound to maintain this Child for me, I to priſon, and be whipt preſently.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Maintain that Child? what ha you got a Baſtard ſince you came to Town already?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: 'Tis a Beggar-womans Baſtard, I never ſaw in my days before.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Get a Baſtard of a Beggar-woman in a days time? do they breed ſo faſt in London? that's faſter than our tame Coneys do; no wonder, London is ſo full of People.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: An't like your Worſh • p, I never ſaw, or touch'd the Woman, or any Woman I never lay with any Woman in my life; give me a Book, I'll kiſs it upon it.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: How could you come by this Baſtard then?

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: I did not come by it, it came by me; I gave a Beggar-woman the bag of Money to hold, whilſt I cufft with the Thief's Man that would have ſtole you, and ſhe lays down the Baſtard, and runs away with the bag of Money.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: How, loſt my bag o' Money; then be whipt, I'll keep none o' the Baſtard.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Then come along, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Have pitty on the poor fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Man,
sp.p: No, ſince he would not keep my bag o' Money, I won't keep his Baſtard.

sp.speaker: Boob.
sp.p: Oh, an't like your Worſhip, be but bound for me; I'll keep it my ſelf—I'll ſerve it out.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Well then Applewoman, ſince I am Married, do you keep my Man Booby's Baſtard for nothing; that ſhall be for a Portion with your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I don't care if I do, the Child is a fine likely Child.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Well, I ſcorn to be beholden to you, I will pay for the keeping of it; but Booby, I will ſend you down quickly into the Countrey, if you get Baſtards thus faſt,

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Mr. Conſtable, diſcharge the Man, I'll ſee that the Gentleman, his Maſter, perform his word.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Well then, o' your word, Sir Thomas, I releaſe him.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: So, I have come up to London to a very fine purpoſe; I ha loſt my Miſtriſs, loſt my Money, am Married to an Apple-womans Daughter, and muſt keep a Beggar-womans Baſtard; whereas, I thought to have liv'd in London, and never ſeen the Countrey more: I will now do down into the Countrey, and ſpend all my time in rayling againſt London: I will never ſee London more, ſo much as in a Map, I will burn my Map of London that hangs in my Parlour-

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: A very Honeſt, and as the times are, Pious and Wholſome Reſolution, Sir Mannerly; better live in the Countrey, and burn your Map of London, than live in London, and ſpoil your Map of Humanity, with Drinking and Wenching.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: I, Son-in-Law, better go into the Countrey, and live lovingly with my Daughter, than ſtay in Town, and turn her away, and keep a Wench in her ſtead, as Gentry do that Marry, and live here.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Why, do they?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ay, the more ſhame for 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Man.
sp.p: Then I'm reſolv'd I'll ſtay in London, and Booby, you can find Baſtards; do you find a Wench for me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Keep a Wench under my Winny's Noſe, I'll tear her Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I will diſſwade him, well, Sir Mannerly, I am very ſorry for the misfortune you have met with in coming to Town for my Alliance; I will cancel the Bond to make you ſome recompence; and ſince my Daughter is not ſo happy to injoy you, let my Houſe have the Honor to entertain you; whither I alſo invite the reſt of this Noble Company: my Lady Faddle and her Husband, my Lord Drybone, and his Settlement; and Tom Raſh, and thy Wife, be of our Society now; this Noble Alliance has advanc'd thee; be a Knight to day, and Prince of Porters for ever, and thy Wife, Lady of Apple-women: I will have both your Statues made in Ginger-bread, and ſet up in Coſtermongers-Hall, and Noble Brides and Bridegrooms all walk in,
sp.l: And Love apace, as faſt as you can drive,
And may the Trade of Love for ever Thrive.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
Spoken by Sir Mannerly Shallow, the Countrey-Wit.
div.l: BRothers, I'm newly come to Town from Cumber-Land, to be one of your ingenious Number.
I am afraid, I ſhall diſgrace you all,
But I'm reſolv'd; I will a damning fall;
Since you have ten ill Plays, for one good Play,
I think to damn 'em all, the ſafeſt way.
But I in all things, Sirs, ſhall copy you,
And ſave or damn, as you great Judges do.
As for the Poet, who is try'd to day,
I know him not, and ſo can little ſay;
If all in his Petition here, be true
He did not write this Play (Great Wits) for you.
He ſays, long ſince, you mighty Judges ſwore,
That you would never ride this Circuit more;
That you have ta'ne the Malefactor napping,
He writ for Wits of London-Bridge and Wapping.
Who hate to ſee a Muſe in Buskings ſtrut,
As much as in gilt Coach, a gawdy Slut,
That his defence, he's unprepar'd to make,
Yet for an Honor does your Preſence take,
〈…〉 ayes, he does it more Renown eſteem,
〈…〉 by you, than to be ſav'd by them.
〈…〉 for my ſake, let all his faults be wav'd,
〈…〉 not the firſt damn'd Poet I have ſav'd.
